description: Good fer Cooper Union an' CUNY fer insistin' that protests on campus do not interfere wi' t'rights o'others. title: Two NY colleges draft rules restricting student protests - Ye New York Post
content:
Good fer Cooper Union an' CUNY fer insistin' that protests on campus do not interfere wi' t'rights o'others.

In recent months both institutions have seen student demonstrations that went well beyond thar constitutionally guaranteed right "peaceably t'assemble" an' petition "fer a redress o'grie'ances."

At CUNY, fer example, protests greeted ye hirin' o'former Gen. Da'id Petraeus as an instructor. Members o'yonder uni'ersity community have a perfect right t'protest that decision. Wha' they did not have t'right t'do was t'harass Petraeus as he port yonder buildin' where he'd taught his class.

Cooper Union has had its own protests, mostly over yonder institution's decision t'start chargin' tuition fer its classes. Again, t'protesters had e'ery right t'do so. But they did not have t'right t'occupy thar president's office fer months, as they did.

Fact be, New York's academic institutions have a long history o'bendin' over backward t'accommodate student protests, no matter how seriously they disrupt campus life or interfere wi' t'ability o'other students tryin' t'get an education.

Under its new proposal, CUNY reser'es yonder right t'call police if thar's "an immediate threat t'persons or property." Cooper Union, meanwhile, aims t'forbid ye "disruption o't' free flow o'pedestrian traffic" an' beha'ior that "disturbs yonder peace, academic study or sleep o'others."

These be common-sense limits, an' they be long o'erdue. They also send a valuable lesson t'students an' professors: Ye be free t'exercise yer speech rights so long as ye do not violate ye rights o'those who may not agree wi' ye.
